title: Push to identify people with cancer-indicating mutation
text:
A crucial step in identifying this group is published in the Medical Journal of Australia today.

It establishes the cost-effectiveness of routinely testing every bowel cancer tumour in the country for Lynch syndrome.

Over their lifetime, 40 to 50 per cent of people with this syndrome – who are not under surveillance – will develop bowel cancer.

When a tumour is confirmed to be linked to Lynch syndrome, the patient will be identified and genetic testing will then be available to all at-risk adult relatives.

Over time, this should identify many people with the condition.

For patients who already have bowel cancer, the identification is beneficial because this cancer can return. If they're aware they have Lynch syndrome, they can take precautions against it and other cancers.

It’s also beneficial because their family members can be identified.

Advertisement

Research 'plugs a huge gap'

The study, conducted by Cancer Council Australia, found this routine testing would potentially prevent 80 bowel cancer deaths a year.

Adjunct Professor Karen Canfell, senior author and chair of the council’s Screening and Immunisation Committee, said this would mean about 165 extra colonoscopies a year in this high-risk group to prevent one bowel cancer death from Lynch syndrome.

She says Australia already has guidance recommending systematic testing for Lynch syndrome in newly diagnosed bowel cancer patients.

“This comprehensive analysis of all the testing possibilities, completes the circle,” Professor Canfell said.

At the moment, when you find you have it, you find yourself in a vacuum of support and care. — Susan Morris, Executive Director at Lynch Syndrome Australia

Testing is currently being considered by the Medical Services Advisory Committee in Canberra, which advises on reimbursement on the Medical Benefits Scheme.

If approved, this testing would supplement the national program that mails out bowel cancer tests to all Australians aged 50 to 74.

Advertisement

This year, it is estimated 16,400 Australians will develop bowel cancer and 5,600 will die from it. An estimated 3 per cent will have Lynch syndrome.

Susan Morris, Executive Director at Lynch Syndrome Australia, says that while it can be “very confronting” to be diagnosed, it can also be “a relief” because it provides an explanation to families who have endured a long history of cancers.

“This research plugs a huge gap. Of the estimated 100,000 Australians with the mutation, only about 5 per cent of us know we are affected," she said.

“Finding and protecting these families is our first priority. At the moment, when you find you have it, you find yourself in a vacuum of support and care.

“This research is just the start of a system to provide support and co-ordinated care for people with Lynch syndrome across Australia.”

Cancer Council Australia encourages families with a high occurrence of the cancers mentioned above to see their GP and ask about genetic testing or to call 13 11 20 for more information.
description: Most people with Lynch syndrome don't know they have it. They also don't know it puts them at great risk of developing one or more aggressive cancers.
